abstract.para: This guide contains an overview of &productnamearch; on the &rpireg; platform and will guide you through the setup procedure.

sect1.title: Platform overview
sect1.para: To use &productnamearch; on the &rpi;, a 64-bit &armreg; compatible &rpireg; is required. &productnamearch; &productnumber; is tested to work on &rpi3; Model A+, Model B, Model B+, and &rpi4; Model B boards as well as on &rpi; Compute Module 3 and 3+ on MyPi Industrial IoT Integrator Board.

sect2.title: Technical details of the &rpi3; model B
sect2.para: The &rpi; is a series of small single-board computers based on a System-on-a-Chip (SoC) by &brcmreg;, featuring various peripherals on the board.

variablelist.title: Selected features of the &rpi3; model B/B+

listitem.para: The &brcm; BCM2837 SoC includes a quad-core &cortexreg;-A53 Application Processor supporting the &armv8; 32-bit and 64-bit instruction sets. With the default configuration, it is clocked up to 1.2 GHz.
1024 MiB DDR2 memory mounted on the back of the board.
&vc4reg; providing &openglesreg; 2.0 support. Displays can be connected over &hdmireg;, composite (TRRS jack), or &mipidsireg; (ribbon cable).
A USB Ethernet controller on the board provides 10/100 Mbit/s Ethernet (Model B) or 10/100/1000 Mbit/s Ethernet with a maximum throughput of 300 Mbit/s (Model B+).

The BCM43438 chip on Model B supports IEEE-802.11b, IEEE-802.11g, and IEEE-802.11n in the 2.4 GHz band. It also provides Bluetooth 2.0 to 4.1 (Low Energy). The BCM43455 chip on Model B+ supports IEEE-802.11b, IEEE-802.11g, IEEE-802.11n, and IEEE-802.11ac in the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands. It provides Bluetooth 4.2 (Low Energy).
The µsdhc; card slot allows for a memory card to be inserted as the primary boot medium.
A total of four USB 2.0 ports are available.

sect2.title: &productnamearch; &productnumber;
sect2.para: &productnamearch; is the first fully supported commercial Linux operating system product available for the &rpi;. You can purchase subscriptions which entitle you to receive all released bug and security fixes, feature updates, and technical assistance from &suse;'s worldwide support. Learn more about subscription and support options at .

note.title: Trial version
note.para: If you want to try out &productnamearch; &productnumber; on the &rpi;, &suse; will provide you with a trial version. This gives you access to free patches and updates for a period of 60 days. You must sign in to the &scc; at using your Customer Center account credentials to receive this free offer. If you do not have a Customer Center account, you must create one to take advantage of the trial version.

sect3.title: Differences compared to &rpios;

listitem.para: &rpios; uses a kernel with modifications especially for the &rpi;. &productnamearch; uses the default &sle; kernel for &aarch64;, which is derived from the official mainline kernel.
&productnamearch; on the &rpi; is the first distribution for the &rpi; using the &aarch64; instruction set.

In &rpios;, the kernel is loaded directly. This is not supported by &productnamearch;, where the U-Boot boot loader is used to provide an EFI boot environment. A GRUB2 EFI binary is chain-loaded to provide a graphical boot screen.
&appliancename; uses Btrfs as the file system for the root partition. Compression is enabled by default for better SD card performance.

sect3.title: &yast;
sect3.para: &yast; is the installation and configuration framework for &sle;. It is popular for its ease of use, flexible graphical interfaces and the capability to customize your system quickly during and after installation. &yast; can be used to configure your entire system: You can configure hardware, set up networking, manage system services, and tune your security settings. All these tasks can be accessed from the &yast; control center. To start it, choose &yast; in the menu or run the command xdg-su -c yast2. You will be prompted to enter the password of the &rootuser; user.

textobject.phrase: The &yast; control center

sect3.para: When started, &yast; shows an overview of available modules (). Simply click an icon to open a module.

sect1.title: Installation
sect1.para: &appliancename; is distributed as an XZ-compressed image file for µsd; cards. This section will guide you through the process of preparing the card for the first boot. If you already have a µsd; card containing the image, you can skip this section and go straight to .

note.title: SD card space requirements
note.para: It is recommended to use a card with a capacity of at least 8 GB.

warning.title: All data on the card will be lost!
warning.para: By following the procedure below, all data on the SD card will be overwritten and therefore irrevocably lost. Be very careful when choosing the destination device of the image writing process.

sect2.title: Preparing the card on Linux
sect2.para: Before and after you plug in the SD card, run the lsblk command. Between the two runs of lsblk, there should be a difference of one or more lines. The first column and first row is the name of the node representing the SD card in your system. To write the image to the card, use the dd command:

example.title: Writing the image to the card using dd
example.para: This command decompresses the image SLES&product-ga;-SP&product-sp;-Minimal-Image.aarch64-&product-ga;.&product-sp;-RaspberryPi-GM.raw.xz to the SD card mmcblk0:
example.screen: &prompt.user;xz -cd SLES&product-ga;-SP&product-sp;-Minimal-Image.aarch64-&product-ga;.&product-sp;-RaspberryPi-GM.raw.xz | sudo dd of=/dev/mmcblk0 bs=4096 iflag=fullblock status=progress

sect2.title: Preparing the card on &mswin; operating systems
sect2.para: The following steps will guide you through the installation of the image onto the SD card on &mswinreg; operating systems. You need to meet these prerequisites:

listitem.para: Latest available image of &appliancename;
Easy 7-Zip from
Win32 Disk Imager from

step.para: Open the downloaded image using Easy 7-Zip. Extract the file content into a directory with sufficient free space.

textobject.phrase: 7zip extraction dialog

step.para: Run Win32 Disk Imager and select the extracted file as Image File. Then, choose the correct drive letter as Device. Click Write to start the procedure.

textobject.phrase: Win32 Disk Imager Writing Process

note.title: Finding the correct device
note.para: If you are unsure which drive letter to choose from in the list, remove the SD card and run Win32 Disk Imager again. The option that disappeared is the right target device.

sect2.title: Preparing the card on &macos;
sect2.para: The following steps will guide you through the installation of the image onto the SD card on &macosreg;. You need to meet these prerequisites:

listitem.para: Latest available image of &appliancename;
The Unarchiver from

step.para: Open Finder at the location where the downloaded image is stored. Use the Open With selection to choose The Unarchiver instead of the default Archive utility and extract the content into a directory with sufficient free space.

textobject.phrase: Open the Image with The Unarchiver

step.para: Open a Terminal window and change into the destination directory of the uncompressed image. Enter diskutil list before and after the SD card is inserted to find out which device to use.
Run diskutil unmountDisk /dev/diskX, where X is the disk number from the previous step.
Run sudo dd bs=4096 if=imageFile.raw of=/dev/diskX, where X is the disk number and imageFile.raw is the name of the uncompressed image.
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;dd bs=4096 if=SLES&product-ga;-SP&product-sp;-Minimal-Image.aarch64-&product-ga;.&product-sp;-RaspberryPi-GM.raw.xz of=/dev/disk4 Password: 5550+0 records in 5550+0 records out 5819596800 bytes transferred in 1131.796649 secs (5141910 bytes/sec)

step.para: Now unmount the disk (which is now labelled EFI) as usual.

sect1.title: First boot
sect1.para: To boot the &rpi; from the prepared µsd;, insert the card into the card slot, then connect a display, an Ethernet cable, a USB keyboard, and a mouse. Power the &rpi;. If everything works, you should see text on the screen.

note.title: Operation without mouse
note.para: The &jeos-firstboot; can be controlled using the keyboard only. Each user interface element has an accelerator, shown as a highlighted character. To activate an accelerator, press and the appropriate character.

sect1.para: During the first boot, the system expands to make use of the entire storage card. This operation may take a while.

sect2.title: Initial system setup with &jeos-firstboot;
sect2.para: After the boot is completed, the &jeos-firstboot; leads you through the initial system setup.

note.para: To run the &jeos-firstboot; wizard via a serial connection, you need to remove the console=tty from the kernel command line console=ttyS0,115200 console=tty in &grub; even if there is no HDMI cable connected.

sect2.para: The minimal &jeos; image comes without language selection. After the assistant finishes, you will be able to install and select your system locale. You can start &jeos-firstboot; at any time using the jeos-config command.

note.title: Canceling the &jeos-firstboot;
note.para: If at any point you select to Cancel the assistant, the system will shut down. You can then disconnect the power supply, make any necessary changes, and start over.

sect2.title: Registration process
sect2.para: It is very important to register your &productnamearch; subscription to ensure full functionality of your &rpi; system. The SD card image provided by &suse; contains a minimal set of packages that are intended for the initial boot process and to get your &rpi; onto the network.

When you have registered your &productnamearch; subscription, you can download other packages you may need, such as compilers. The &sls; version that runs on your &rpi; is the same version that runs on &x86-64;, &power;, &zseries;, or on other &arm;-based systems.

important.title: Setting the clock
important.para: Because the &rpi; does not have a persistent Real Time Clock, make sure that the clock is set to the current date and time before attempting to use Zypper or &yast; to install additional packages.

sect2.para: You can initially register your system with the SUSEConnect tool. Afterwards you can also make use of the &yast; Product Registration module.

Set the language as desired:

note.title: Translation packages
note.para: Certain applications may require you to install an additional -lang package before you can see texts translated to the chosen language.

sect2.title: Changing the host name
sect2.para: Follow these steps to change the default host name:

step.para: Open the &yast; network module either by running yast2 lan or clicking the network icon in the &yast; control center.
Select Hostname/DNS in the top tab bar.
Type the new host name into the Hostname field.
Click OK to save the change. After &yast; exits, you need to log out and in again.

sect2.title: Setting up networking
sect2.para: The default configuration has DHCP enabled on the Ethernet port. If that suits your network environment, you can skip this section. If you require the use of a static IP address, use &yast;:

step.para: Open the &yast; network module either by running yast2 lan or clicking the network icon in the &yast; control center.
In &yast;, you will see the network interface being selected. Select the built-in Ethernet and choose Edit to open the address configuration.
Select Statically Assigned IP Address and type in the desired values for IP Address and Subnet Mask. Click Next.

With a static network configuration, you will also need to specify a DNS server (if applicable) and a gateway. For the gateway, select Routing in the tab bar and enter the IPs of the gateways into the specific fields.
The DNS server is set in the Hostname/DNS tab. After choosing that tab, enter the IPs of the name servers into the respective Name Server fields.

sect2.para: Similarly to the procedure described above, &yast; also lets you configure the built-in Wi-Fi network adapter.
For detailed information about the network configuration in &productnamearch;, consult the respective sections of the &sls; Deployment and Administration guides at .

sect1.title: General system usage
sect1.para: After the initial configuration procedure and the first boot of the system, you can now use various components of the system.

sect2.title: Desktop
sect2.para: &appliancename; 15 GA had packages for a minimal X11 desktop (IceWM) preinstalled.

&appliancename; &productnumber; comes as a tiny text-based appliance, allowing you to install any available desktop of your choice or none for headless usage. Should you want to recreate the package selection of the previous images, a pattern x11_raspberrypi is provided for convenience.
If not done already, you will need to enable the Desktop Applications Module. Assuming you have registered the base product already, as described in , the fastest way to enable the module is:
